properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring storm over Eastern Quebec this weekend A coastal low pressure system from New England will reach the Gaspé Peninsula on Saturday. Strong winds and significant snowfall amounts are expected with this system. However, there is still some uncertainty as to the track of this low, which could significantly impact snowfall amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T19:20:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T03:21:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0660923319.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain followed by possibly heavy snow tonight. A system moving through southern Saskatchewan is bringing rain and wet snow to southeastern Saskatchewan and southwestern Manitoba. As this system progresses southward the rain will transition over completely to snow tonight. There is currently a good deal of uncertainty on how fast this transition to snow will occur and with convective elements in the precipitation, there is also uncertainty on total snowfall accumulation. The exact track of the low, the initial melting on warm ground and the capacity of snow to accumulate on higher terrain will all play a role in determining how much snow will accumulate. At this moment, we expect a swath of snow between 5 to 10 cm to fall from Yorkton south to Oxbow and east through Brandon and Pilot Mound. However, because of the uncertainty we cannot rule out locally higher amounts that exceed 10 cm of snow, especially along higher terrain. Snowfall is expected to completely exit the area early Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T18:59:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T05:02:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2225725477.2020

properties.Summary:

Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northerly winds expected throughout the weekend. A disturbance tracking into northern Quebec is bringing strong northerly winds to the Coral Harbour area. Winds gusting at times to 70 or 80 km/h are expected today with even stronger wind gusts of 90 km/h possible on Sunday. These winds will produce blowing snow which may result in blizzard or near blizzard conditions. The public is advised to listen for possible wind or blizzard warnings. The winds will moderate slightly on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T00:21:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T08:22:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2221398962.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The combination of strong northwest winds and snow will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow on Sunday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A late season snowfall in store for some regions of the province. Total snowfall: up to 10 cm for some areas, possibly more especially over the Cape Breton Highlands.. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h, Location: northern and western Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight into Sunday. Remarks: Periods of snow and strong winds are expected to develop this evening over western Nova Scotia where westerly winds blow onshore. These conditions are forecast to spread eastward across northern Nova Scotia later tonight, reaching the Cape Breton Highlands during the overnight hours. Conditions will improve Sunday morning over western areas of the province, and later in the morning or in the afternoon over eastern regions. Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea levels are expected. Locations: the Nova Scotia coastline of the Bay of Fundy, including the Minas Basin. Time Span: from 11:00 p.m. this evening to 3:00 am on Sunday. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system will pass just north of Nova Scotia today. This will give storm surge combined with waves approaching the Fundy coast of the province from the west, as well as large spring tides this weekend. The combined effects may cause minor flooding. If the storm track or intensity changes, storm surge warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T23:45:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T07:46:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1558463628.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Locations: South to west facing coastlines from Sheet Harbour west into Shelburne County then north into Yarmouth County. Time Span: from 7:00 p.m. to 11:00 pm this evening. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system will pass just north of Nova Scotia today. This will give storm surge combined with waves approaching the Atlantic coast of the province from the southwest. The waves combined with the storm surge may cause minor flooding. If the storm track or intensity changes, storm surge warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 30 cm are expected. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly gusts to 60 km/h tonight into Sunday, except 80 km/h over the Acadian Peninsula. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Snow will spread from Maine to the northeast this morning and increase in intensity this afternoon and evening. As temperatures remain near freezing, snow will likely be heavy and wet. Snow may mix with rain along parts of the Bay of Chaleur and northeast coast. Precipitation will taper off by Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-09T23:29:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T07:30:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2804675521.2020

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will drop to near or below the freezing mark overnight tonight. In addition, the relatively cool weather for this time of the year will continue for several more days. As a result, the frost advisory for Southwestern Quebec could be maintained for all nights and mornings through the rest of this week, possibly through Wednesday morning. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T00:44:12-00:00

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Potential breaking sea conditions and overwash warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on May 9, 2020. An intense low pressure system approaching from New England will give strong winds on Sunday over the regions specified below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high-amplitude tides could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast in the vicinity of the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Matane: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallee: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T00:47:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-09T08:48:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1172689563.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Below freezing temperatures this morning followed by near or below freezing temperatures each night through early Wednesday. Hazard: Frost and freeze conditions. Timing: This morning and tonight. Likely again Monday night and Tuesday night. Impact: Frost-sensitive crops and plants could be damaged or killed by frost. Action: Take preventative measures to protect frost-sensitive crops and plants. An extended period of significantly colder than normal temperatures will result in several days of frost and, at times, hard freezes across much of Southern Ontario. These conditions are expected to persist through Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
